list.item: School closed unexpectedly Mar. 24 because of smallpox scare - Everyone scatters
I stay till April 6th on because of DAR Congress in Washington which I am to attend as delegate & page

div1.p: Sunday night again - I wonder how many more before I see you all again? Will be so glad to get out of the mountains and into a city again & not see another mountain-city of any sort for awhile!

The days have passed off very quietly since I wrote the rest of my letter to you last Friday morning. Evelyn left after lunch - goes to Knoxville tomorrow & then on through Ohio - back to New York and around at all the chapters & clubs - will be gone nearly two months. I made out the attendance report of the whole
school - my grades - took a nap - then cleaned up my room & sorted over my possessions prepatory to packing. Spent the evening reading to Aunt L. from Little Lord Fauntleroy & to myself as she & Mrs. P. went off to bed a little after eight. Yesterday (Saturday) I hemmed on the machine all morning - you remember Jane we didn't finish some that should have been done. The next excitement was going after the mail - which at present is sorted & distributed in the old schoolhouse at the corner of our grounds & which Charlie has used for a storehouse. A little card announcing the arrival of Mary Leanor Shinvers
and my papers were all I got - Saturday is an off day with me. Aunt L. & Mrs. P. are so funny together. They walked part way down the school walk & then waited for me - they were not fixed up so wouldn't go all the way - were very anxious to get the Sevierville weekly - the Vindicator and always read everything - the notices of deaths & marriage licenses first! We sat on the porch & read them. It was a perfect day - then friend Tom came over to tell me about his plans for next year - is finally about decided to go to Georgia again - to school - Expects to haul lumber for Mr. Huff this summer & stay with them - the girls & his father will do the farming. You ought to see the way the youngsters have to get out & hoe these stoney fields - They and the women work as hard if not harder than the men. After Tom left I mended - we had supper & read in the evening - This morning I was awakened by thunder & rain - such a surprise as last evening was perfect & not a sign of a change of weather was to be seen. Had planned all week to walk down to Banner with Maud Clabo & spend the day with her aunt - Ruth - but of course the bad weather put an end to all that.

So I put in a busy morning & part of the afternoon with more mending - let out all
my white petticoats for one thing. They rang the first bell for Sunday School but guess no one went - that is of the older ones for the second bell didn't ring & I saw some of the youngsters leaving early. We planned to go over to Huff's this p.m. - but guess they all went to the hotel for could not get them over the phone & Aunt L. said there was no smoke - Anyway it was pretty stormy most of the p.m. so doubt if we would have gone anyway.

Aunt L. made bread today - She usually does on Sunday -
so for supper we had hot rolls - chocolate & jelly.
Tomorrow am going to make some calls in the p.m. - don't know just where yet - that depends on the weather - but shall get out & go somewhere regardless!
Mrs. P. & Aunt L. are so restless - sit around the fire - nothing to do - they can't read much or sew either because of their poor eyesight - I feel sorry for them.

The frogs are "hollering" as loud as can be. Such
lovely bluebirds as I've seen - and the redbirds - Oh, my - the reddest things imaginable all over - like a flash of fire - I've written for a room at the Farragut Hotel in Knoxville - but no doubt by the time you get this & a letter in reply gets across the U.S. I'll be on my way to Washington D.C. a letter from you at Mrs. Helmick's would be very nice. Ther She is trying to sell their house so it may be when I get there they will be gone - but in that case she was going to find a boarding house for me. Last summer when I visited Hazel & Rodney at the lake a friend was with them - a Dorothy Rogers who works in one of the gov. bureaus in Wash. D.C. I looked up her address the other day & found she was at the Cochran Hotel - so know of one reliable place to fall back on if necessary.
Will bring this scribbling to a close for this time. Hope all is well with you and that my letter of last Sunday is rousing you to think of Washington D.C. - Please do!
Loads of love to you all as ever
